title: HW5 Solutions
content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Attached are solutions to HW5. Feel free to ask questions about them in this thread:</paragraph><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/xHf1THUKAJkdneDCDIsqFDML" filename="hw05_solution.pdf"/><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/GJGCf5elX1QPeUPHDGUO9zoO" filename="q_coding_dropout_sol.ipynb"/><file url="https://static.us.edusercontent.com/files/thE7EzWQsa6FruyPKMT5Lvqz" filename="q_coding_bn_drop_cnn_sol.zip"/></document>
document: Attached are solutions to HW5. Feel free to ask questions about them in this thread:

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Regarding 4(c), I believe λ must be taken into account. <break/>Wouldn't λ^(1/2)* w_tilde = Γ w be right?</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Regarding 4(c), I believe λ must be taken into account. 
Wouldn't λ^(1/2)* w_tilde = Γ w be right?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Why isn't there an edge from u to sigma^2 for 6a?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Why isn't there an edge from u to sigma^2 for 6a?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>There’s no edge from <bold>u → σ²</bold> because σ² is computed from <bold>X</bold>, not from <bold>u</bold> in the graph structure. The mean is not an input to the variance node.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: There’s no edge from u → σ² because σ² is computed from X, not from u in the graph structure. The mean is not an input to the variance node.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The edge is omitted because the gradient of the variance with respect to the mean sums to zero</paragraph><math>\sum_{ }^{ }(x_i-\mu)=0</math><paragraph>, effectively allowing them to be treated as parallel branches derived directly from <bold><italic>X</italic></bold> for the purpose of backpropagation. </paragraph></document>
comments.document:
The edge is omitted because the gradient of the variance with respect to the mean sums to zero

$$\sum_{ }^{ }(x_i-\mu)=0$$

, effectively allowing them to be treated as parallel branches derived directly from X for the purpose of backpropagation.
